pull.title: net: fix use-after-free in tests
pull.body:
In PeerLogicValidation::PeerLogicValidation() we would schedule a lambda
function to execute later, capturing the local variable
`consensusParams` by reference.

Presumably this was considered safe because `consensusParams` is a
reference itself to a global variable which is not supposed to change,
but it can in tests.

Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/18372

net: fix use-after-free in tests

In PeerLogicValidation::PeerLogicValidation() we would schedule a lambda
function to execute later, capturing the local variable
`consensusParams` by reference.

Presumably this was considered safe because `consensusParams` is a
reference itself to a global variable which is not supposed to change,
but it can in tests.

Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/18372

events.message:
net: fix use-after-free in tests

In PeerLogicValidation::PeerLogicValidation() we would schedule a lambda
function to execute later, capturing the local variable
`consensusParams` by reference.

Presumably this was considered safe because `consensusParams` is a
reference itself to a global variable which is not supposed to change,
but it can in tests.

Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/18372

events.body:
Configure and run as:
`./configure --with-sanitizers=thread`
`./src/test/test_bitcoin --run_test="txvalidationcache_tests/checkinputs_test"`

I confirm the following:
* Latest master @ ce87d5613 shows the [use-after-free](https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin/bitcoin/jobs/663676100#L4588) bug
* This PR fixes the bug
* Reverting fadafb83c on top of the latest master `git show fadafb83c |git apply -R -3` (+ trivial conflict resolution) fixes the bug
* The failure seems to be deterministic

So, this was introduced in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18289. I have no clue why travis [was green](https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin/bitcoin/builds/660635839?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification) for it.

```diff
-    scheduler.scheduleEvery(std::bind(&PeerLogicValidation::CheckForStaleTipAndEvictPeers, this, consensusParams), EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL * 1000);
+    scheduler.scheduleEvery([&] { this->CheckForStaleTipAndEvictPeers(consensusParams); }, std::chrono::seconds{EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL});
```

Indeed `std::bind()` copies the arguments whereas the introduced lambda function passes them by reference and will brick if the argument is destroyed before the function is called.

ACK 7d8e1dec3b26074df1533f715871f79c956cc224


> In PeerLogicValidation::PeerLogicValidation() we would schedule a lambda
> function to execute later, capturing the local variable
> `consensusParams` by reference.
> 
> Presumably this was considered safe because `consensusParams` is a
> reference itself to a global variable which is not supposed to change,
> but it can in tests.

Correct, it is a reference to a global, which I assumed to not change after initialization. This does not hold for unit test, for example the txvalidation one:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/ce87d5613a5537b68cf23e7bc25c1e3770704ff9/src/test/util/setup_common.cpp#L160-L166

issue.title: refactor: Make scheduler methods type safe
issue.body: Main benefit is that stuff like `15 * 60 * 1000` is replaced by `minutes{15}`

events.body:
Concept ACK -- premature optimisation is the root of many lifetime issues :)

Somewhat related: [Investigate potential lifetime issues in cases where we are returning "const std::string&"](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/17198).

This is a great talk about recurring C++ bugs at Facebook: [this segment on lifetime issues due to premature optimization](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkgszkPnV8g&t=876) might have some relevance here :)

ACK 7d8e1dec3b26074df1533f715871f79c956cc224

> > [] premature optimisation is the root of many lifetime issues :)
>
> I don't think it is helpful to call this premature optimization. 

Point taken :)

issue.title: Check for successful runs of all checks
issue.body:
Note: This is just a rough draft and the code does currently not work as the [Github checks API is only available in preview mode](https://developer.github.com/v3/checks/runs/#list-check-runs-for-a-specific-ref). It just supports the discussion on the issue.

Background: Among all the Travis shenanigans the last two days I noticed that one of my PRs did not run the Travis check at all. However, when Appveyor succeeded [the PR appeared to be ready to merge, since all checks passed](https://imgur.com/a/Jb0oj45). I am not sure if it could have actually been merged at this point but the Github UI definitely suggests it and that seems to be easy to miss. A few hours later when Travis came back it appears that the Travis check ran then.

Through the Github checks API it would be possible to check that all checks have run and passed. The code here is just a rough draft of how this can work. At the moment the checks API appears to not respond with any actual data.

issue.title: Bitcoin PR tracking
issue.body: The main purpose of this issue is to keep track of Pull Requests on Bitcoin since version 0.19.1 identifying those which make a porting LitecoinZ.

issue.title: test: Activate segwit in TestChain100Setup
issue.body:
This fixes not only a TODO in the code, but also prevents a never ending source of uninitialized reads. E.g.

* #18376
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19704#issuecomment-678259092
* ...

comments.body:
I think this can  be made `=` to just mirror what `std::bind` did. (`this` is a pointer, so it shouldn't matter whether it is copied or referenced, and for consensusParams we want it to be copied).

```suggestion
    scheduler.scheduleEvery([=] { this->CheckForStaleTipAndEvictPeers(consensusParams); }, std::chrono::seconds{EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL});
```

The `=` is also what is recommended in the "Tutorial" (written by me, so count that against me):

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/3a8d25064e700ff2e69600cc1ede597751283a85/src/scheduler.h#L28

In that case I'd prefer to use `[=, this]`, but this might not compile either on our current C++ target? According to the page you linked:

```cpp
    [=, this] {};   // until C++20: Error: this when = is the default
                    // since C++20: OK, same as [=]
```

So, given that we won't be switching to C++20 any time soon, I'd still prefer the `[=]`. Then it can be changed, if and when we switch to C++20?

Just a nit, though. ACK from me either way.
